author: Rachel Bishop
title: Want to go on holiday to Spain or other EU countries? You could soon be forced to pay for a visa

British holidaymakers may be forced to pay to visit countries such as Spain or Italy post-Brexit, it has emerged.
Brussels says “the system will apply to visa-exempt third country nationals”, which Britons are set to become as of March 29, 2019, according to the EU’s agreed Brexit negotiating guidelines.
It comes after an agreement was reached by the Bulgarian Council presidency and European Parliament representatives for the European travel information and authorisation system (ETIAS) on Wednesday.
The move, which is intended to “protect the European Union’s external borders” to allow European Parliament “to stop those who may pose a threat to our citizens”, will see an end to free movement for UK citizens between the 27 other EU nations.
If the proposals are voted in, Brits will need to pay 7 Euros (around £6) to submit an online ETIAS application to the Brussels authorities.
Valentin Radev, the Bulgarian interior minister, said: “Today’s agreement is another important step in protecting the EU’s external borders. The iconic hotel skyscraper skyline of Benidorm and Levante Beach (Image: iStockphoto)
“By knowing who is coming to the EU before they even arrive at the border, we will be better able to stop those who may pose a threat to our citizens.”
The EU announcement reads: “ETIAS will allow for advance checks and, if necessary, deny travel authorisation to visa-exempt third-country nationals travelling to the Schengen area. Brexit
